ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the different elements of what makes fiction fiction and how to build a story. As a person who never saw themself writing fiction before this class, I felt it was both a challenging but well-explained introduction to the genre.

I learned how to tell a story! Before class, I had never really tried creative writing, but I left with a greater appreciation of how wonderful writers have built their craft as well as how to build my own.
I learned the traditional structure and fundamentals of writing a story. I also learned which of those fundamentals are most important.

Quite simply, in Reading Fiction for Craft, I learned how to write a short story from beginning to end. In the first half of the semester, we spoke about the different fundamental aspects of storytelling in published works and in the second half of the semester we were then asked to apply what we discussed to our own writing.

Prof. Sexton breaks down fiction writing into a couple of different skills like characterization, narrative building, voice etc... and does an excellent job of introducing writers to these necessary components of fiction writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think mid-semester some of the reading got to be a bit much (given the amount of writing we were expected to do).

Prof Sexton is wonderful!! He is definitely a strength in this course. The readings were all super helpful. I am struggling to think of a weakness, but I think even more small writing exercises could be fun, though not necessary.

The course moves at a very fast pace, reading two books a week sometimes, and when those books arent discussed to the fullest degree, sometimes it feels like it isnt necessary to read them in the first place. The exercises are a very good way to work on craft elements. And the books themselves are good. However, it doesnt feel like all the work we do in the course is accurately reflected in the grade for the course, which is a fault of the course.

I loved this course, I felt as if it was organized in a way that I was able to focus on one aspect of storytelling at a time--a huge strength for someone who has never done any fiction writing before.  There are some weeks, especially at the beginning of the semester, where there is way too many readings and writings to do and then in the second half of the semester, the workload settles down substantially--I wish the readings were more so dispersed throughout the semester, but I also acknowledge that that may make the workshopping aspect of the course difficult to continue with. Beyond this, I wasn't a huge fan of all of the readings and I wish that we were to do more readings similar to the length of the 2500 word short story that we were asked to write at the end of the semester.
It was just so fun! The class wrote entertaining stories, and Prof. Sexton fostered the classroom environment where we became friends with our peers by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The break-out rooms were nice, and I liked how Prof Sexton employed the chat feature to get us talking/thinking at the beginning of class.

I loved that in the seminar format over Zoom, students were still able to form the same close bond characteristic of most creative writing courses at Yale. I felt as if keeping the microphone unmuted worked really well in our class and it encouraged students to actively participate. The one Zoom feature that I didn't love was the use of the chat function as a means of discussing the texts, there were too many thoughts all at once and I felt as if it was difficult to both read everyone else's thoughts and respond to them in only about 5 minutes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course for anyone looking to get their feet wet in fiction writing!
Yes!! Prof Sexton is amazing and the class is so much fun! You won't regret it!
I think its a very good introduction to writing. However, if you want to write a lot and workshop that writing with a seminar, there are other classes that better serve that purpose.
Yes! If you want exposure to creative writing and specifically fiction writing, I definitely recommend this course! It's super manageable and Professor Sexton is really great! :)

Yes! Definitely try to take this course if you want to be a writer in the future, or if you were like me and wanted to reignite your passion for pleasure reading. I hear people at Yale always saying "I wish I read more", and if that's really the case they should take this course and use it to once again become excited to pick up a book when you have free time.
